awd_abstract_narration:
Non-Technical Description 
This project studies how sound waves move in a new class of atomically-thin, two-dimensional (2D) materials using a laser-based technique, how to alter this motion using chemistry, and how to use this knowledge to enhance technologies. Sound waves in solid materials move in the form of "phonons," which act like individual particles of sound. Phonons can carry heat and affect electrons that carry electrical currents, impacting material devices and application. This project will further the understanding of the phonon properties of 2D materials, filling a major gap in our fundamental knowledge. This work trains undergraduate and graduate students for careers in science and engineering. Educational and broader outreach goals include: (i) development of a publicly available online Brillouin spectroscopy database, (ii) initiation of an annual one-day Sciimpact-East conference to introduce underserved high school students and teachers in the Providence, RI area to careers in science and technology, and (iii) recruitment of under-represented minority and female high school students and undergraduates to participate in scientific research.

Technical Description 
This award supports a project to understand the phononic properties of two-dimensional (2D) chalcogenide (S, Se, Te) and oxide materials to match our current understanding of their electronic properties. Brillouin laser light scattering will be used to map the acoustic phonon dispersion relations of 2D materials, synthesized in-house. Novel intercalation chemistries will be introduced toward systematically controlling the interlayer phonon behavior by chemically modulating the layer-to-layer coupling. Defects (voids, vacancies, and grain boundaries) will be engineered into 2D materials using chemical methods for investigating their impact on fundamental phonon behavior. This effort lays the foundation for the complete understanding and the chemical control of phonons in 2D chalcogenide and oxide materials and will guide understanding of mechanical behavior, heat transport and device failure in future applications of 2D materials.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Acoustic phonons in 2D materials

Two-dimensional, atomically-thin materials offer significant technological promise in future applications. As 2D layered materials become integrated into new technologies, their acoustic phonons, which are quantized sound waves in a material, impact heat transport, interfere with electronic transport, and alter material mechanical properties. Understanding phonons in 2D layered materials, and devising chemistries to make these new 2D materials while controlling acoustic phonons, is essential for new electronic devices and mechanical applications. We use a laser-based instrument technique called Brillouin light scattering to measure acoustic phonons and extract mechanical properties.

In this project:

-       We developed new synthesis of 2D layered materials including V2O5 and MoO3.

-       We developed new chemical techniques to intercalate zero-valent metals into bulk, mm-sized layered crystals yielding new optical properties.

-       We expanded zero-valent intercalation chemistries in layered materials to include: Ag, Au, Bi, Co, Cr, Cu, Fe, Ge, In, Mg, Mn, Mo, Nb, Ni, Os, Pb, Pd, Pt, Rh, Ru, Sb, Sn, W. 

-       We developed chemistries to intercalate more than one element into a 2D layered material (dual intercalation).

-       New polytypic phase transitions were found in Cu, Co, and Fe-intercalated Bi2Se3.

-       Brillouin scattering spectroscopy was used to measure acoustic phonons and mechanical properties in several layered materials including hBN, MoO3, V2O5, and CdPS3.

-       We chemically tuned the quantized acoustic phonon dispersion in 2D layered MoO3 using zero-valent intercalation.

-       Zero-valent intercalation was used to alter elastic properties in V2O5, MoO3, and h-BN.

-       Data analysis and computational techniques were developed to analyze Brillouin scattering of (i) atomically thin materials and (ii) of polycrystalline, highly defected materials.

-       Enhancement of Brillouin signal was found with Cu-intercalation where experiment time in layered materials was reduced from hours to minutes.

-       Just over 1000 Brillouin laser scattering spectra of acoustic phonons in 2D materials were collected in the course of this work.

Public & Scientific Outreach: We developed a publicly available, online Brillouin spectroscopy database. This is a site where the public, academic, industrial, and scientific communities can access information on Brillouin spectroscopy, and download Brillouin spectra from standard materials. New guides to mathematics behind Brillouin scattering and how to take Brillouin peaks to elastic properties have been added.

       http://koski.ucdavis.edu/BRILLOUIN

K-12 Education: A high school student from Hope High School in Providence RI, at which 83% students identify as African-American or Hispanic-American. was recruited to join our group and participate in research.

Undergraduate Education: Almost 40 undergraduate students were recruited to join efforts in this project over its lifetime. Targeted recruitment was used to bring in military veterans (7), women (21), and minorities (8).  Undergraduate students contributed significantly to this project resulting in co-and first authorship on publications submitted from this grant.

 


Last Modified: 12/22/2022
Modified by: Kristie J Koski

Images (1 of )

por.por_txt_cntn:
Acoustic phonons in 2D materials

Two-dimensional, atomically-thin materials offer significant technological promise in future applications. As 2D layered materials become integrated into new technologies, their acoustic phonons, which are quantized sound waves in a material, impact heat transport, interfere with electronic transport, and alter material mechanical properties. Understanding phonons in 2D layered materials, and devising chemistries to make these new 2D materials while controlling acoustic phonons, is essential for new electronic devices and mechanical applications. We use a laser-based instrument technique called Brillouin light scattering to measure acoustic phonons and extract mechanical properties. 

In this project:

-       We developed new synthesis of 2D layered materials including V2O5 and MoO3.

-       We developed new chemical techniques to intercalate zero-valent metals into bulk, mm-sized layered crystals yielding new optical properties.

-       We expanded zero-valent intercalation chemistries in layered materials to include: Ag, Au, Bi, Co, Cr, Cu, Fe, Ge, In, Mg, Mn, Mo, Nb, Ni, Os, Pb, Pd, Pt, Rh, Ru, Sb, Sn, W. 

-       We developed chemistries to intercalate more than one element into a 2D layered material (dual intercalation).

-       New polytypic phase transitions were found in Cu, Co, and Fe-intercalated Bi2Se3.

-       Brillouin scattering spectroscopy was used to measure acoustic phonons and mechanical properties in several layered materials including hBN, MoO3, V2O5, and CdPS3.

-       We chemically tuned the quantized acoustic phonon dispersion in 2D layered MoO3 using zero-valent intercalation.

-       Zero-valent intercalation was used to alter elastic properties in V2O5, MoO3, and h-BN.

-       Data analysis and computational techniques were developed to analyze Brillouin scattering of (i) atomically thin materials and (ii) of polycrystalline, highly defected materials.

-       Enhancement of Brillouin signal was found with Cu-intercalation where experiment time in layered materials was reduced from hours to minutes.

-       Just over 1000 Brillouin laser scattering spectra of acoustic phonons in 2D materials were collected in the course of this work.

Public & Scientific Outreach: We developed a publicly available, online Brillouin spectroscopy database. This is a site where the public, academic, industrial, and scientific communities can access information on Brillouin spectroscopy, and download Brillouin spectra from standard materials. New guides to mathematics behind Brillouin scattering and how to take Brillouin peaks to elastic properties have been added.

       http://koski.ucdavis.edu/BRILLOUIN

K-12 Education: A high school student from Hope High School in Providence RI, at which 83% students identify as African-American or Hispanic-American. was recruited to join our group and participate in research.

Undergraduate Education: Almost 40 undergraduate students were recruited to join efforts in this project over its lifetime. Targeted recruitment was used to bring in military veterans (7), women (21), and minorities (8).  Undergraduate students contributed significantly to this project resulting in co-and first authorship on publications submitted from this grant.
